info.title: Rediscover DevOps configuration
info.description:
This document describes the specification of the 
proposed file **.well-known/devops.json** that can 
be used in the DevOps CI/CD as identifier for
information required by the tools. 

By using the .well-known location, assumptions are
reduced if not eliminated by the automation tools.

The end result is a design using HATEOS principles where further
information on a resource can be obatined by following the bread crumbs of the 
relationships in the **.well-known/devops.json** file.

Automation tools can also validate the information during 
source commit to confirm the engineers are providing the necessary 
information and that it is valid.

The **devops.json** file has been defined using OpenAPI but that does not imply that
a real API needs to be deployed or used.  On the contrary it is unlikely that the main
copy stored on Git is accessed via a API service.  The **devops.json** file can also
include a AsyncOpen definition, so the one definition **devops.json** definition
can support a single compute resource that handles both synchronous and asynchronous
service models for a subject domain.

You could build a catalogue service of all your **devops.json** definitions linked to
Git definitions, but that is not a specification requirement.

For further information see https://github.com/meerkat-manor/rediOps

owner-contact.title: asset-owner
owner-contact.description:
The name and /or contact detals of the DevOps owner.

The owner can be a single person or a team.  It is preferale that it is more
granular then the organisation.

If you have a CMDB catalgue then the entry here should match the details on
the CMDB if you choose to include them here.

The contact details do not include a phone / mobile / cell number on purpose
as this information is either know by the reader for the person / team or
can be obtained from an organisations internal directory.

Automated tools are unlikely to benefit from having access to a phone number, but they
can send emails or post messages to Slack.

email.description:
The email adress of the owner.

The email address could be a distribution list.

web.description:
A web page URL for the owner.

The web page could refer to a team page.

name.description:
The name of the owner.

This may be persons or teams name.

contacts.description:
List of contacts

The list is allowed to contain duplicates of electronic 
contact names (types) but not addresses.

activity-model.title: activity
activity-model.description: Describes the activity that the engine will perform

config.description: A configuration file that can be an URL location or a Git folder

script.description:
A command or script file that is executed to perform the activity.

The choice of activity processing engine is up to the organisation, or 
some assumptions can be made based on file extension.

For example:

* .sh = Bash
* .ps1 = PowerShell
* .bat = MS DOS command

The activity engine name along with catageory can link to
configuration item for qualifying the processing engine.

The directory where the command is executed is
based on the root of the repository and if not found
then the current directory is used.

There is a maximum length of the string that can be stored.

activity.description:
Engine used for activties.

For example the engine name can be:

* azure-pipeline
* circle-ci
* jenkins

_Note_: The engine category can be **BUILD**, **DEPLOY**,
**INSTALL**

platform.description:
The platform that the activity is configured for.

A platform is an evironment such as Windows, Linux, iOS, Android, etc

An empty value is considered as executable on any platform.  For example
a .PS1 PowerShell script could execute on Winows and Linux. If you always
expect to execute on a specific platform then there is no need to supply a value.

The special value of **"any"** is hardcoded into processing.

Minimum suggested values are:

* linux
* winodws
* darwin

You could also qualify further to align with your CI/CD
software, using such values as:

* Windows-10
* Windows-11
* Linux-Redhat
* Windows-desktop
 
and so on

CI servers can also have their own repository for generated artifact

tools-model.description:
The purpose of the tools section is an aid to identify the various tols required 
during build, testing and deployment.  This can server as a documentation item 
or actually preparing the nevironment to contain the necessary tool.

If you are using a well defined tool that is linked to your source versioning by
web hook then you are not likely to require this section for execution. 

A sample use case for a simple environment is to identify a tool that needs
to be fetched from an artifact storage location as it is required by the 
deployment install script.

For example you can define it as "powershell" to execute script file with extension .ps1

You cannot combine different commands for different processors in the one tools set.  If you have different
processors you can define multiple tools. 

_Note_: The engine category is **TOOL**

dependency-model.title: dependency-action
dependency-model.description:
The dependency section provides information on:

1. Calls to a system of record either as a database call or another service (e.g. REST) call
2. Other OpenAPIs that the service calls as a synchronous request and response
3. Other AsyncAPIs that the service as a publish fire and forget async call
4. Other APIs that the service calls such as ODBC, authentication, logging
5. Tools that are required for build, testing and deployment
 
The information provided here can help documenting the deoendencies for the 
CMDB, cross reference the code, enable gateway configuration 
and produce sequence diagram

apis.description:
List of downstream dependency APIs.

The list can include:

1. RESTful APIs
2. SOAP APIs
3. Event or AMQP APIs
3. File transfer APIs
4. ODBC or JDBC connections

No credentials are required to be captured in the definiton. Please do not include user names or passwords.

response.description: The expected response body from a healthy service

unique_id.description:
Unique identifier

Do not use the Git repository URL as the unique identifier because

The owner may not be netllectual Property / Copyright owner as the

name.description:
A name for the resource this document covers.

If there is a CMDB catalogue then the name here should match the

asset.description:
Resource information that is intended to be related to a Computer Management Database (CMDB).

By linking to the asset in an CMDB, further information can be retrieved.

If the CMDB link exists then it should be considered the authorative source where the same information exists in this definition.

If you wish the DevOps workflow to control the information and be versioned with Git, then you can use this information to push updates to the CMDB.  Just include processing of the __./well-known/devops.json__ into your deployment pipeline and post to the CMDB the updates.

The preference is that the links is in the format of a HTTPS URL to a

repository.description:
Repository links

* Source version control management.  Examples include:
    - Git
    - Mercurial

* Artefact repositories. Examples include:
    - Archiva
    - Artifactory

Describes the dependecies for the resource.

The dependecies include databases, downstream APIS, and build tooks.

build.description: Describes the build process, configuration and script file

Describes the test process, tools and script.

Testing includes verification activities lie code scans, security reviews, code risk analysis,

Information on the health service(s0 supported
by the resource being described in this document.

refresh.description:
The Refresh section gives information on refreshing the resource on the server.  
The instructions can be the same as for installing the first time.

The information can be in the form of a Ansibe playbook or commands to 
be executed on the server with the component installed.  You can also execute 
commaonds from a script file that is found on the Git repo.

The information can be in the form of an Ansibe playbook or commands to

apis.description:
List of OpenAPI and/or AsyncAPI definitions.

The list can include Git and REST versions, because before build the API might not be available
as a REST service.

A resource may have multiple definitions files or even different versions.

There is also the ability to use WSDL specifications.

tags.description:
A list of free format tags for the root of the **devops** definition.

The tags can be used for things such as:
* identify application type
* additional tools applicable

governance.description:
Governance details for the asset described 
by the RediOps definiton.

deploy.description:
The Deploy section gives information on installing the resource onto a server.
The detection on whether the resource is already
installed is not defined in the specifications.

The information can be in the form of an Ansible playbook or commands to 
be executed on the server.  You can also execute 
commands from a script file that is found on the Git repo.

The deploy section can also conain release information and 
activities.

metadata_url.description:
A URL to additional, custom metadata.

This metadata in the file, probably in JSON or YAML, format
can have any custom schema.  The data in the metadata file
can be used by process as required.

One use case is as template data for generating code,
configurations, scripts or commands.

The **qaskx-cli** tool is able to parse and use
JSON, YAML, and YML formatted files as input
data to templating.

For qaskx-cli the URL can be an internet file
or local file.

schema.description:
The rediOPs schema.

This includes the version of the schema that
your definition represents.

rel.description:
The relationships for the resource as hypermedia link.

The common values are:

* self : this resource.  Normally used in lists,
* first : the first resource in a list, 
* last : the last resource in a list, 
* next : the next resource or page in a list, 
* prev : the previous resource or page in a list
* parent: the parent resource for the item
* collection: list of children of the resource
* buy: link to purchase the investment
* sell: link to sell the invetsment, assuming the investor has holdings
* quote: link to quote for the asset
* icon : URL to the icon for the resource
* video : URL to a video
* external : URL to external content
* content : inline (HTML or markdonw) content related to the resource
* price : link to resource (product) unit price
* price+collection : link to list of historical unit prices
 
The "rel" value is also dependent on context.  There is no prices or ability to buy/sell marketplace itself and therefore these resources will not provide a "buy" link for instance.

A buy/sell link are expected to be POST requests and therefore the "operation" will need to be considered.  If perdforming a "POST" then the caller will need to know the JSON model for the POST, if the media type is "application/json" as an example.

operation.description:
The operation that the service resource accepts.

Commonly this will be a GET or POST

media_type.description:
The type of resource media type that the link refers to.

Examples are:

* application/json
* text/html

caption.description: A caption that can be displayed for the link

healthfull-model.title: health-model
healthfull-model.description:
The response object from a "health" request.

The response may be full. partial, minimal or missing 
if the status is not "200"

status.description:
Indicates whether the service status is acceptable
 or not
 
 indicates whether the service status is acceptable
   or not.  API publishers SHOULD use following values for the field:

* "pass": healthy (acceptable aliases: "ok" to support Node's
      Terminus and "up" for Java's SpringBoot),

* "fail": unhealthy (acceptable aliases: "error" to support Node's
      Terminus and "down" for Java's SpringBoot), and

* "warn": healthy, with some concerns.

   The value of the status field is case-insensitive and is tightly
   related with the HTTP response code returned by the health endpoint.
   For "pass" status, HTTP response code in the 2xx-3xx range MUST be
   used.  For "fail" status, HTTP response code in the 4xx-5xx range
   MUST be used.  In case of the "warn" status, endpoints MUST return
   HTTP status in the 2xx-3xx range, and additional information SHOULD
   be provided, utilizing optional fields of the response.

   A health endpoint is only meaningful in the context of the component
   it indicates the health of.  It has no other meaning or purpose.  As
   such, its health is a conduit to the health of the component.
   Clients SHOULD assume that the HTTP response code returned by the
   health endpoint is applicable to the entire component (e.g. a larger
   API or a microservice).  This is compatible with the behavior that
   current infrastructural tooling expects: load-balancers, service
   discoveries and others, utilizing health-checks.

notes.description: Array of notes relevant to current state of health

output.description:
Raw error output, in case of "fail" or "warn"
states.  This field SHOULD be omitted for "pass" state.

description.description:
A human-friendly description of the
service.

checks.description:
The "checks" object MAY have a number of unique keys, one for each
   logical downstream dependency or sub-component.  Since each sub-
   component may be backed by several nodes with varying health
   statuses, these keys point to arrays of objects.  In case of a
   single-node sub-component (or if presence of nodes is not relevant),
   a single-element array SHOULD be used as the value, for consistency.

   The key identifying an element in the object SHOULD be a unique
   string within the details section.  It MAY have two parts:
   "{componentName}:{measurementName}", in which case the meaning of the
   parts SHOULD be as follows:

   *  componentName: (optional) human-readable name for the component.
      MUST not contain a colon, in the name, since colon is used as a
      separator.

   *  measurementName: (optional) name of the measurement type (a data
      point type) that the status is reported for.  MUST not contain a
      colon, in the name, since colon is used as a separator.  The
      observation's name can be one of:

      -  A pre-defined value from this spec.  Pre-defined values
         include:

         o  utilization

         o  responseTime

         o  connections

         o  uptime

      -  A common and standard term from a well-known source such as
         schema.org, IANA or microformats.

      -  A URI that indicates extra semantics and processing rules that
         MAY be provided by a resource at the other end of the URI.
         URIs do not have to be dereferenceable, however.  They are just
         a namespace, and the meaning of a namespace CAN be provided by
         any convenient means (e.g. publishing an RFC, Open API Spec
         document or a nicely printed book).

   On the value side of the equation, each "component details" object in
   the array SHOULD have at least one key.

release_id.description:
In well-designed APIs, backwards-compatible
changes in the service should not update a version number.  APIs
usually change their version number as infrequently as possible, to
preserve stable interface.  However, implementation of an API may
change much more frequently, which leads to the importance of having
separate "release number" or "releaseId" that is different from the
public version of the API.

api-model.title: api
api-model.description:
Commonly a link to the API definition in OpenAPI, AsyncAPI or WSDL format.

The definition file can be source from various locations, with
the most common being either Git or REST (HTTPS) accessible 
locations.

A Git file can be accessed with Git command while REST / HTTPS
might use the "wget" or "curl" commands

release_id.description:
In well-designed APIs, backwards-compatible
changes in the service should not update a version number.  APIs
usually change their version number as infrequently as possible, to
preserve stable interface.  However, implementation of an API may
change much more frequently, which leads to the importance of having
separate "release number" or "releaseId" that is different from the
public version of the API.

The release identifier is required for dependencies in recognition
that under source versioning, the same API may have multiple
versions recorded - such as in the past and the curent version.

service_id.description:
A unique identifier (CI or UUID) for the service definition.
This is not the instance identifier, such as the host name or IP (v4/v6)
of the computing resource.

This can be something like the conguration item defned in a CMDB

url.description:
A full URL for the API specification or if the value is partial
then the location is assumed to be on the Git repo.  That is the host name and
Git name are the same as for the "devops.json" file.  The URL should also
account for API version.

If the resource details are being supplied by a catalogue service
then the value in the "repository" section will be used.

This is not the URL for the API implementation as that 
value is expected to be stored with the deployment information
such as a CMDB.

format.description:
The format or type of specification.  The defined formats are:

* OpenAPI
* AsyncAPI
* WSDL
* Custom

Other formats can be added in future versions, and allowance is made for 
a custom, in-house format.

_Note_: This is not the format of the actual document such as YAML or JSON or XML.

guide.description: Link to documentation for the topic

api.description:
The engine that the Url refers to.  As the Url format is used by various 
processors, an engine value is required for proper processing.

The acceptable values will depend on the organisation, but the
minimal values that need to be supported are:

* GIT for Git located resources.  For this case the Git resource is assumed 
  to be in the Git repository for this DevOps resource if the prefix is not
  HTTPS
* REST for HTTP/S based web pages that are no explicitly handled by other engines

Other possible values might be:

* FILE for local or LAN based resources 
* S/FTP for FTP based URL resources
 
_Note_: The engine category is **API**

name.description:
A short name for the API.  This is best auto populated
from a CMDB based on the CI, but alternatively can be
manually entered.

econtact-model.description:
Electronic contact model

This type can be used to defined additional contact
methods such as Slack or Mastodon or Microsoft Teams.

name.description:
This is the name of the electronic name used for the contact.

The names have not been enumerated so as to allow additions and new
entrants.

For example Slack might be defined as SLACK.

The choice of names are set by the consumer, though the recommended names
for common contact names are:

* SMS
* SLACK
* TWITTER
* MASTODON
* MATRIX
* MSTEAMS
* JABBER
* THREADS

_Note_: Uppercase name have been selected to denote these constants

governance-model.description:
Governance details for the resouce being
described by the RediOps definition

data_classification.description:
Rating for data.

The higher the number the data integrity controls and assurance is required.
It is up to the organisation to
select their ratings scheme, but it is important it is consistent across all assets.

availability_rating.description:
Rating for availability.

The higher the number the more available the asset is.  It is up to the organisation to
select their ratings scheme, but it is important it is consistent across all assets.

resiliency_rating.description:
Rating for resiliency.

The higher the number the more resiliant the asset needs to be to failure.  
It is up to the organisation to
select their ratings scheme, but it is important it is consistent across all assets.

cyber_rating.description:
Rating for cyber.

The higher the number the more cyber controsl are required for the asset.  
It is up to the organisation to
select their ratings scheme, but it is important it is consistent across all assets.

commands-model.title: commands
commands-model.description: Commands are executed by the engine.  The commands need to be constructed in a format compatible with the engine.

pre.description: Commands if any that are executed before the script and post items.

script.description:
A single script thais executed after the "pre" and before the "post" commands.
The script can be an URL or a file within the version control (e.g. Git) repository.

post.description: Commands if any that are executed after the script.

platform.description:
The platform that the activity is configured for.

A platform is an evironment such as Windows, Linux, iOS, Android, etc

An empty value is considered as executable on any platform.  For example
a .PS1 PowerShell script could execute on Winows and Linux. If you always
expect to execute on a specific platform then there is no need to supply a value.

The special value of **"any"** is hardcoded into processing.

Minimum suggested values are:

* linux
* winodws
* darwin

You could also qualify further to align with your CI/CD
software, using such values as:

* Windows-10
* Windows-11
* Linux-Redhat
* Windows-desktop
 
and so on

engine-model.title: engine
engine-model.description:
Engine details as used for apis, build, testing, configuration and deployment

If a tool is used and the URL is an input then it is expected that the 
tool will understand the content/format of the input.

category.description:
Category of the engine

The category value is dependant on the context
of the engine model.

name.description:
A common name for the engine or tool, such as:

* make
* teamcity
* jenkins
* Gitlab
* Bamboo
* Travis
* azure-pipeline
* go-build
* dotnet
* docker
* concourse
* circle-ci
* drone-ci
* woodpecker-ci

The choice is up to you but you should keep it consistent.

Tools such as the **qaskx-cli** will understood some names and be
able to execute the script or commands.  Please refer to **qaskx-cli**
documentation at https://docs.qaskx.one/qaskx-cli/

url.description:
Link to engine or its configuration

The format of the URL will depend on the engine.

Commonly the format will be of a URL such that 
it begins with "https" but some categories such as 
a docket repository does not expect the the "https"
prefix.

An executable ARTIFACT may also describe a file system
object and not a Uniform Resource Locator of the common format.
